title: What’s in a Logo? How 2016 Designs Stack Up
content:
The launch of a presidential campaign brings with it the launch of a new campaign logo , a candidate 's calling card for yard signs , bumper stickers and social media .
Sometimes , logos become closely associated with the candidate 's brand . President Barack Obama is known for the modern logo his campaign used in the 2008 race – an image of a sun rising , inside an “ O ” that was often featured next to “ Obama ” or as the “ O ” in “ Hope. ” As he campaigned , Mr. Obama often wore the logo as a lapel pin , instead of an American flag .
But not all logos are so well-received . Already , social media critics and branding experts are picking over the 2016 field -- and finding problems .
As Hillary Clinton launched her campaign Sunday , her new campaign logo took criticism on several fronts . Some thought it resembled a road sign , maybe one might see for a hospital . Others noted that it was pointed right , with the New Yorker cartoonist Emily Flake showed two people looking at the logo saying “ I ’ m just not entirely sure a big red arrow pointing right is the best logo for a Democratic candidate , is all . ”
Other Twitter users pointed out that the arrow has a corporate look , with the arrow having some resemblance to the FedEx delivery company 's logo .
“ Hillary is going to have enough problems seeming warm and genuine and this looks like an industrial shipping logo , ” says James Young , owner of Tangible UX , a design consulting firm . Still , Mr. Young calls Mrs. Clinton 's logo his favorite out of all the presidential candidates in the 2016 race so far .
Another observer had an interesting theory -- that turned sideways , the logo may symbolize for rising equality .
Everyone is hating on the @ HillaryClinton logo . But flip it 90 degrees and it 's an equal sign whose stock is rising . pic.twitter.com/In7yLaXDFn — Ben Fractenberg ( @ fractenberg ) April 13 , 2015
Republican Sens . Rand Paul and Ted Cruz entered the race a week apart with logos that could easily be confused for each other . They both feature a flame .
Designer Tanisa Sharif calls them a snooze . “ Both to me are a little bit on the boring side , ” she said .
There is one issue with Mr. Cruz ’ s logo – the flame is decorated with stars and stripes . “ It looks like a flag in flames , ” said Ms. Sharif . “ I think this is the case where there is too many ideas coming into one symbol . “
The symmetry in the flame in Mr. Cruz ’ s logo also makes it look like a tear drop , says Mr. Young , who also didn ’ t have kind words for Mr. Paul ’ s logo .
“ It looks like the first thought that came out of a junior designer ’ s head and that they went with it , ” he said .
Mr. Cruz and Sen. Marco Rubio ( R. , Fla. ) are both opting to use their full names . Mrs. Clinton is focusing readers on her first name – perhaps in an effort to show a friendlier side , Ms. Sharif said . Mr. Paul is using his first name , an effort that may also be deliberate .
“ Rand Paul is just this figure out there , but Rand is the guy I could go have a beer with , ” says Mr. Young .
Mr. Rubio 's campaign logo uses the shape of the continental United States to dot the i in his name . That left some people wondering why he left off Alaska and Hawaii .
Is the America Rubio put over the `` i '' in his name missing Alaska and Hawaii ? Are we sure he loves ALL of America ? — Gabe Ortíz ( @ TUSK81 ) April 13 , 2015
As for which candidate ’ s logo wins for being the most presidential , Mr. Young says that depends on what voters are looking for . Mr. Cruz ’ s use of a serif font – with “ feet ” on the lettering – hearkens back to tradition . Mrs. Clinton ’ s logo is more modern . Typography website Fonts In Use identified the font used by Mrs. Clinton as “ Unity ” – while also calling the logo uninspiring .
The “ H ” symbol also works well for social media sites that often require a square photo , a factor that shouldn ’ t be forgotten , says Aaron James Draplin of Draplin Design Company . Candidates using their full names will find it harder to fit the square . To get around that , Mr. Paul and Mr. Cruz are using their faces instead of their logos on social media .
Sill , all of the candidate ’ s logos are missing a feature – and Mr. Young applauds them for it . None of the logos feature a waving flag , an emblem used in past campaigns , including Mrs. Clinton ’ s first run for president in 2008 .
Vote : Which candidate 's campaign logo do you like the most ?
